item.title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm
item.description: Background Definition: an abdominal aortic aneurysm is an abnormal dilatation of the abdominal aorta so that its diameter is >3cm or 50% greater than the expected diameter Causes Inflammation secondary to atherosclerosis, hypertension, infection, trauma, arteritis Connective tissue disorders Risk factors Non modifiable: male gender; age; family history; connective tissue disorders (Marfans, Ehlers Danlos) Modifiable: smoking; hypertension; hyperlipidaemia Screening Men over 65 Abdominal duplex ultrasound Below indicates the indications for referral and consideration of intervention.

item.title: Acute limb ischaemia
item.description: Background Acute limb ischaemia is a sudden decrease in arterial perfusion of a limb which threatens it viability The limb can survive for between 4-6 hours before irreversible tissue damage Acute on chronic limb ischaemia is usually secondary to thrombosis in patients with pre-existing arterial disease where atherosclerotic plaque rupture leads to lumen reduction and thrombosis Causes Causes can be divided into embolic and thrombotic Thrombotic causes account for 80-85% of cases Thrombotic causes include: atherosclerosis; low flow (congestive cardiac failure; hypovolaemia); arteritis; external compression; dissection; hypercoagulation, malignancy Embolic causes include: atherosclerotic plaque or thrombus from the heart, more proximal arteries or aortic/peripheral aneurysms; valvular heart disease (rheumatic, bacterial); iatrogenic; trauma; paradoxical emboli Risk factors: Non modifiable: age Modifiable: hypertension; hyperlipidaemia; smoking; diabetes; obesity; cancer Presentation Acute limb ischaemia is characterised by the 6 P’s: pain; pallor; paraesthesia; paralysis; pulselessness; perishing cold.

item.title: Acute Type B dissection
item.description: Definitions Acute aortic syndrome includes aortic dissection, intra-mural haematoma (IMH) and penetrating aortic ulcer (PAU), which are a spectrum of conditions with similar presentation and management Aortic dissection occurs when there is a breach in the intima (inner layer of the vessel wall) and blood tracks between the intima and media, leading to a true and false lumen An aneurysm is a 50% increase in the normal diameter of a vessel.

item.title: Carotid Disease
item.description: Presentation Carotid disease is often asymptomatic It is usually diagnosed when individuals are investigated for a stroke or TIA Carotid artery plaques may embolise and cause symptoms of stroke/TIA/amaurosis fugax Risk Factors Non modifiable: age; family history Modifiable: Hypertension; hyperlipidaemia; smoking; diabetes; obesity; sleep apnoea Diagnosis Initial investigations include bloods, ECG (assess for AF as source of emboli), CT head (to assess for cerebral infarction) Degree of carotid stenosis on duplex ultrasound Management MDT decision is recommended to achieve consensus for treatment Best medical therapy is recommended for all individuals with carotid disease.

item.title: Diabetic Foot
item.description: Summary Background Diabetic foot disease includes: infection; ulceration and tissue loss Diabetic foot disease affects just under 6% of people with diabetes Foot ulceration increases an individuals risk of infection and amputation Complications can be prevented with good foot care and screening These patients require a multi disciplinary team to provide comprehensive care to prevent these complication Causes Types of diabetic foot ulcers include: Neuropathic – secondary to peripheral neuropathy Ischaemic – secondary to peripheral arterial disease Mixed – a combination of neuropathic and ischaemic Peripheral arterial disease Diabetes causes damages to blood vessels by inflammation and atherosclerosis.

item.title: Superficial Venous Disease
item.description: Background Varicose veins are dilated and tortuous veins Superficial veins drain into the deep veins through the deep muscle fascia via the perforator veins Valves prevent back flow of blood from deep to superficial veins Varicose veins develop when the superficial vein valves become incompetent, leading to the reflux and pooling of blood in the superficial veins The great saphenous vein, short saphenous vein or perforators may be affected A saphena varix occurs when there is dilatation of the great saphenous vein at the junction with the femoral vein Causes: Primary: usually idiopathic Secondary: intravascular disease (DVT); extravascular disease (pelvic mass) Risk factors Non modifiable: Age; female gender; family history Modifiable: pregnancy, previous DVT, previous trauma to the lower limb Presentation Symptoms: pain (dull ache, heaviness or burning); pain worse after standing and relieved with leg elevation; nocturnal leg cramps; itching Signs: haemosiderin staining; venous eczema; oedema; lipodermatosclerosis; ulceration Complications: ulceration; bleeding; thrombophlebitis; DVT; reduced quality of life Diagnosis Clinical diagnosis Duplex ultrasound can identify location of varicosities and degree of reflux to guide treatment Duplex ultrasound can assess the deep venous system.

item.description: Summary Presenting complaint Pain: SOCRATES Aneurysm: Usually asymptomatic but patients may report abdominal or back pain Peripheral arterial disease: A cramping type pain in the buttock or calf which occurs with exertion, usually at a consistent distance. The pain is relieved by rest. Ask how far the patient can walk before they have pain/need to stop (claudication distance). In critical limb ischaemia, individuals describe rest pain or night pain, which is relieved by hanging the foot over the edge of the bed.

item.title: Vascular Investigations
item.description: Doppler Principles Uses the change in frequency of sound waves reflected off a moving object Used to determine the velocity of blood Triphasic waveform represents a healthy vessel. Biphasic and monophasic represent a diseased vessel wall. Triphasic: Phase 1. In systole, blood accelerates forwards Phase 2. At the end of systole, a drop in pressure leads to reverse flow in the vessel Phase 3. Elastic recoil in the vessel wall leads to forward flow in the vessel Biphasic: Occurs when vessels lose their elasticity Loss of phase 3 Monophasic: One sound produced Represents vessel damage Loss of phases 2 and 3 Indications Assessment of pulses Calculate ABPI Advantages Non invasive Quick and convenient Limitations Limited information You can never find a hand held Doppler on the ward!
